 Even though the teacher has a degree on the topic doesn't mean that they can teach it well. It means they learned it well. I have found that some of the best teachers had straight C's, if that, because they can connect with more students. 
 My Chemistry teacher is a prime example. He is the genius of our school. Unfortunately, since he learns quickly, he assumes everyone does. I didn't suffer from this, but the majority of the students nearly failed his class. 
 Aslo, even though parents may not know the subjects as well (though some do) they know you better than your teacher does. They know how to encourage you, and they know your strenghts and weaknesses, and more importantly, your learning style. 
 Once again, being homeschooled does not cut you off from the rest of the world. You still socialize, and meet more people. More importantly, you are not restricted to people your age, like you are in a class room. I had friends 5-10 years older than me when I was homeschooled, and they taught me things my parents couldn't, and teachers couldn't. 
 I think homeschooling is better off in the long run.

Thought I'd chime in with my two cents. Personally, I see the merits in homeschooling as they've been pointed out here, specialized attention, learning at your pace, less exposure to the "dangerous" elemetnts that may leak into some public schools, etc etc. 
 
 However, I would, and do, support public education over homschooling, for a few reasons. One, with public education you set a standard everyone has to reach. Granted, I'm sure plenty of homeschoolers already surpass this standard, but there are some who do not, and if they had been in a public school, they might have made it. Teachers, counselors and other staff are trained to watch for kids who are falling behind, while a parent may have all the good intentions on the world but not be able to realise their child is slipping. 
 
 Two, it has been said that homeschooling does not make one anti-social, and I'll agree with that. But I think that public school forces one to socialize to the xtent that they will be prepared in a much more thorough way for the real world. We all know it isnt roses and sunshine out there, and being exposed to some of the tough decisions in a public school can make sure people are prepared for what is ahead. 
 
 Thirdly, it has been said over and over in this thread that public schools all suck, they teach garbage, etc etc. I would disagree wholeheartedly with this statement. Sure, we hear about the horror cases that some inner-city schools have become, but believe me, this is the exception, not the rule. I attended one of the best public school systems in the country, and recieved an education that I would deem far superior to what my parents could have taught me. Now, before anyone lambasts my parents for being stupid, just let me tell you both have PhDs, my mother is in charge of the heat shield division of NASA, and my father teaches at Cal, one of the top public universities in the country, if not the world. 
 
 Finally, a public school opens one to many varrying points of view. From teachers and students, one can see a whole spectrum of thought, religion, belief, and creed. Homeschooling however tends to be dominated by religious parents who want to instill their beliefs in their children. Now, there doesnt happen to be anything wrong with wanting your children to share your beliefs, but it is only fair to allow them to se the other choices out there first. Sure, it is possible to know about other views if you're homeschooled, but it isn't as forward and direct, one must go above and beyond to see what others are like. 
 
 Ok, I think thats enough for now, my hands are gettin sore from typing all that.
